The rain in Huddersfield had a personality; a persistent, nagging misery that seeped not just into the mortar of the old wool mills but into the very bones of the people who walked the slick, cobbled ginnels. It wasn't a cleansing rain. It was a grey, mithered thing that clung to windows and made the world outside the pane a watercolour blur. Sergeant Arthur Hamerton, a title he no longer used but couldn't quite shed, watched it from the vestry window. It was a Tuesday. The scent of old wood, beeswax, and a faint, lingering dampness was the perpetual incense of St. Jude’s. Arthur preferred it to the cloying sweetness of the actual incense his predecessor had favoured. This scent was honest. It smelled of age, of endurance, of the slow, inevitable return of all things to the earth.

He was polishing the chalice, a simple silver cup that was his only real indulgence. His predecessor had also favoured a gilt monstrosity studded with chips of coloured glass, but Arthur had quietly retired it to a felt-lined box in the crypt. His own chalice was unadorned, heavy in his hands, its surface reflecting a distorted, wide-angled version of his face: a long, thinning face, bracketed by ears that seemed too large, and eyes that had settled into a permanent state of weary watchfulness. The face of a clergyman. But the hands polishing the silver were not a clergyman's hands. They were thick, the knuckles scarred, the grip sure and economical. The hands of a Sergeant. A Sergeant of the Church Army, a title that confused most of his parishioners and suited him just fine. It was a halfway house between two lives, a role that embraced both the sword and the word, though his sword these days was pastoral care and a belief in the fundamental decency of his flock. A belief the rain was always trying to erode.

The telephone, a stern black Bakelite thing on his desk, jangled with an abruptness that cut through the quiet hum of the rain. He picked it up, the cool plastic familiar against his ear.

"St. Jude's. Vicar Hamerton speaking." He never used 'Sergeant'. It felt like a boast.

"Arthur? It's... it's Brenda." The voice was thin, stretched tight with a panic that hadn't yet found the release of tears. Brenda Riley. Her mother, Agnes, was eighty-six, a cornerstone of the church’s knitting circle and a woman whose memory for town history was both a blessing and a curse.

"Brenda, what is it? Is everything alright?" He kept his voice low and even, a practised calm he’d spent years cultivating.

"It's Mum. She... she wasn't answering. The milk's still on the step from yesterday. I used my key, Arthur. I'm in the hall. Oh, God. The smell..." Her voice cracked, a dry, rasping sound. "There's something wrong. I can't... I can't make myself go into the lounge."

"Stay where you are, Brenda. Don't go any further. I'm coming right now." He put the receiver down without waiting for a reply, his movements suddenly precise, all languid contemplation gone. He shrugged on his old tweed jacket, its elbows patched with worn leather, and was out the vestry door in seconds, the rain hitting his face with a sudden, cold shock. He didn't bother with an umbrella. The rain was just a fact of life, like sin. You could try to shield yourself from it, but eventually, you were going to get wet.

Agnes Gable lived three streets away, in a row of stone-fronted terraces that clung to the hillside like stubborn limpets. The houses were respectable but tired, their small front gardens tidy, their windows veiled with net curtains. A police car was already parked clumsily on the pavement outside number seventeen, its blue light rotating with a silent, methodical rhythm that seemed obscene in the quiet, grey street. A small knot of neighbours stood on the opposite pavement, their faces pale and drawn, their umbrellas a cluster of black mushrooms. They nodded at Arthur as he passed, a collective, silent gesture of deference and dread. He was the vicar. His arrival made it official. This was a tragedy.

A uniformed constable, a lad so young his stubble looked like a faint pencil smudge, stood at the open door. He recognised Arthur and his expression softened with relief. "Vicar. Glad you're here. The daughter's in a right state."

"I'll see to her," Arthur said, stepping over the threshold. "Who's in charge?"

"DI Miller, sir. He's through there." The constable jerked his chin towards the lounge.

Brenda was slumped on the bottom step of the narrow staircase, her face buried in her hands. Arthur placed a hand on her shoulder. It was trembling violently. He said nothing, just stood there, his presence a solid, undemanding weight beside her. That was the first lesson he’d learned, long before the seminary. When there are no words, just be there. The silence was more honest.

After a moment, he walked past her to the open door of the lounge. The smell hit him then, coppery and sweet, the scent of a butcher’s shop left to warm in the sun. It was a smell he hadn't encountered in a decade, but his body remembered it instantly. His stomach tightened, a cold, hard knot.

The room was neat. Obsessively so. China dogs on the mantelpiece, lace doilies on the arms of the floral-patterned sofa, a family photograph from a wedding decades ago. And on the floor, by the hearth, lay Agnes Gable. DI Miller, a burly man whose suit was too tight across the shoulders, was crouched beside the body. He looked up as Arthur entered, his expression a mixture of professional courtesy and impatience.

"Arthur. Didn't expect to see you so soon."

"Brenda called me. She's one of mine, Frank. So was her mother." Arthur’s eyes were fixed on the scene. It was wrong. All wrong. Agnes was lying on her back, her limbs arranged at angles that were not just unnatural, but impossible for a simple fall. Her thin housecoat was soaked through with a dark stain that had spread across the Axminster carpet. But it was the compression that made Arthur's breath catch. Her torso... it was as if a great weight had been placed upon it. As if a car had driven over her. Her face, mercifully turned away from the door, was obscured, but the shape of her head was distorted, flattened against the floor in a way that spoke of immense, deliberate pressure.

"Nasty one," Miller said, standing up with a grunt and wiping his hands on a handkerchief. "Looks like she took a fall, hit her head on the fireplace fender. Must have been lying here a day or two."

Arthur didn't reply. His gaze drifted from Agnes to the floor around her. He saw the deep indentations in the worn linoleum, just beyond the edge of the rug. Four of them. Symmetrical. The marks of something heavy. Something with four square feet, put down and then lifted up again. He looked at the sturdy oak coffee table, the television on its stand. Nothing matched. Nothing in the room could have made those marks, or done... that.

"A fall?" Arthur finally said, his voice quiet. He looked at Miller, whose face was already settling into the easy explanation. The case filed, the paperwork completed. An accidental death. Non-suspicious.

"It happens, Arthur. They get frail. Bones like chalk." Miller clapped him on the shoulder. "Best go see to the daughter. We'll be done here soon."

Arthur nodded, his mind a thousand miles away. He backed out of the room, the image of those four indentations burned into his vision. He went and sat with Brenda, murmuring the useless, necessary platitudes that were the currency of his trade. But as he spoke of peace and God's mysterious ways, another part of him, the cold, analytical Sergeant, was turning over the facts. The impossible angles. The smell of overwhelming trauma. The four square marks on the floor. This wasn't a fall. This was an execution. A pressing. And the person who did it had brought the instrument with them, and taken it away.

A week passed. The rain came and went. The inquest was swift, the verdict recorded as Accidental Death, with a rider from the coroner about the dangers faced by the elderly living alone. Huddersfield sighed a collective, sorrowful sigh, and moved on. The knitting circle was smaller now. Arthur conducted the funeral. He spoke of Agnes’s warmth, her humour, her unwavering faith. He spoke of the Resurrection and the life to come. And all the while, he felt like a liar, because what had happened to Agnes Gable had nothing to do with God. It was something else entirely. Something ancient and brutal that had slouched into a tidy little terrace and left nothing but a stain on the carpet and four mysterious marks on the floor.

It was two days after the funeral that the first one arrived. It wasn't a letter. It was a pamphlet, the sort you might find slipped under your windscreen wiper, advertising a new takeaway or a political party. It was on cheap, grey paper, printed badly, the ink slightly smeared as if done on a faulty photocopier. It had been pushed through the vicarage letterbox along with a handful of circulars and a bill. Arthur almost threw it away. But the title, in thick, crude block capitals, stopped him cold.

A SHORT SERMON FOR THE SLOW.

He took it into his study, the chalice sitting half-polished on his desk, and smoothed it flat. The text was a single, dense block, without paragraphs or mercy. It was a tirade. A torrent of pure, undiluted hatred, written in a style that was both childish and terrifyingly articulate.

"The world is cluttered," it began. "Full of used things. Things that have had their day. Spindly-legged chairs waiting to break. Cracked cups. Rusting cars. And people. Oh, the people. The worst clutter of all. The wrinkled ones, the brittle-boned, the ones who smell of mothballs and regret. They are the dust of the world. They are the beetles scuttling in the dark, all shell and no substance. They take up space. They breathe our air. They tell their boring stories. Their time is UP. I have come to tidy. I have come to put things away. You saw the one in the neat little house? The old beetle? I am the boot. I am the gravity they forgot to fear. I pressed her back into the dust she came from. A mercy, really. A kindness. This is not a judgment. This is housekeeping. There will be more. The clutter must be cleared."

It wasn't signed with a name. Just a crude, spiky drawing at the bottom of the page. A shape that could have been a crown, or perhaps a set of jagged teeth. And beneath it, one word.

REX.

Arthur read it once. Then he read it again, a deep cold settling in his marrow that had nothing to do with the dampness of the old house. The boot. I pressed her. The words resonated with the horror in Agnes Gable's lounge, with the four square marks on the lino. This wasn't a prank. This wasn't some disturbed youth with a printing machine. This was a confession. A manifesto. A promise. He looked from the hateful screed to the silver chalice on his desk, its surface reflecting his own grim face. One represented a covenant of love and redemption. The other, a covenant of hate and annihilation. The Sergeant, the man he tried to keep buried under layers of scripture and pastoral duty, stirred. He folded the pamphlet carefully, tucked it inside his well-worn Bible, and knew, with a certainty that felt like a curse, that this was only the beginning. Frank Miller hadn't started a police investigation. But Rex had. And so, it seemed, had Arthur Hamerton.His first port of call was not the police station. That would come, but Frank Miller was a man who dealt in facts, not feelings, and Arthur knew the pamphlet, on its own, would be dismissed as the work of a crank. He needed more. The Sergeant knew that you didn't go to your commanding officer with a problem; you went with a problem and a potential solution. Or, at the very least, a direction of attack. The pamphlet was a clue, and the first rule of any investigation was to understand your evidence.

He walked not to the station, but to the Huddersfield Library, a grand Victorian edifice of sandstone and civic pride. Inside, the hushed atmosphere was a comfort, a different kind of sanctuary to St. Jude’s. He found a quiet table in the local history section, the scent of old paper and bookbinder's glue replacing the damp of the vestry. He laid the pamphlet on the polished oak. ‘A SHORT SERMON FOR THE SLOW.’ He examined the paper stock. It was cheap, fibrous, the kind of recycled stuff used in schools or community centres. The printing was the key. It was smudged, the letters slightly bloated. It wasn't a modern laser print or a crisp inkjet job. It was toner-based. A photocopier, and an old one at that, with a dirty drum or a failing fuser unit. The sort of machine a church, a community hall, or a small, cash-strapped business might run until it finally died.

He took out his Bible and from the back, tucked into a small pocket in the leather cover, he slid out a pocket magnifier. It was another relic from his old life, a tool for map-reading and inspecting the integrity of equipment. He bent over the pamphlet, his brow furrowed in concentration. The crude drawing of the crown, the ‘REX’ signature. The spikes of the crown were uneven, seven of them, one slightly bent. It wasn't just a doodle; it was a logo, a trademark. Pride. The killer was proud of his work. He wanted to be known, if not by name, then by his sign. The arrogance of it was breathtaking. It was the same arrogance that led him to confess, to taunt. He believed he was untouchable.

His next stop was the police station. The front desk was a fortress of perspex and boredom, manned by a civilian clerk who looked at Arthur’s collar and assumed he was there about the church roof lead. DI Miller was, predictably, ‘in a meeting’. Arthur said he would wait. He sat on a hard plastic chair, the pamphlet a hot coal in his jacket pocket, and watched the slow, drab theatre of a provincial station house: a tearful teenager reporting a stolen bike, a drunk being booked in with weary profanity, the endless crackle of the radio. An hour later, Miller emerged, looking harassed, a file tucked under his arm. He saw Arthur and his face tightened.

"Arthur. I'm up to my eyes. What is it?" He didn't invite Arthur into his office, keeping him in the public waiting area. It was a power play. A clear signal that this was not a conversation he wanted to have.

Arthur didn't waste time with pleasantries. He pulled the pamphlet from his pocket and handed it to the detective. "This was put through my letterbox this morning."

Miller took it, his thick fingers clumsy with the thin paper. He read it, his expression unreadable at first. Then, the corner of his mouth twitched, a flicker of something between amusement and contempt. He folded it and tried to hand it back. "A nutter, Arthur. A ghoul. They crawl out of the woodwork after any reported death. Some people get their kicks this way."

"Read it again, Frank," Arthur insisted, his voice low but steely. "Look at the words he uses. 'I pressed her back into the dust'. How would a ghoul know that? It wasn't in the papers. You and I are the only ones who saw the... the compression. You wrote it off as a fall. No one else knows what was done to her."

Miller’s face hardened. He was a man who didn't like his conclusions being questioned, especially not by a vicar. "It's a lucky guess. A sick turn of phrase. What do you want me to do? Launch a major investigation because some weirdo with a photocopier has a flair for the dramatic? I've got a dozen open cases, real ones, with evidence. I don't have the manpower to go chasing ghost stories."

"This isn't a ghost story. This is a confession. And a threat. He says there will be more." Arthur’s own hands were balled into fists in his pockets, the Sergeant straining against the Vicar's placid exterior. "Look at the marks on the floor in the photos from the scene. The four indentations. He brought something with him, Frank. Something heavy enough to do that to a human being, with four square feet. He brought it in and he took it away. It was a piece of equipment. This was methodical."

"So now you're a forensics expert?" Miller's voice was rising, drawing a glance from the desk clerk. "Agnes Gable was eighty-six and had bones like bird wings. I could have stepped on her and done that kind of damage. It was a tragic accident. The end. Now, I'm busy." He shoved the pamphlet into Arthur's hand. "Go and say a prayer for the sickos of the world, Arthur. It's what you're good at. Leave policing to me."

Arthur stood there for a moment, the flimsy paper a declaration of war in his palm. He looked at Miller's obstinate, tired face and saw a man who had already made up his mind, a man walled in by procedure and budgets and a desperate need for the world to be simpler than it was. There was no help to be had here. Not yet.

He had been rejected, dismissed as a meddling cleric. The feeling was not one of anger, but of cold, sharp clarity. He had been a Sergeant far longer than he had been a vicar. He knew what it was to operate without official sanction, to work in the grey spaces where the rules didn't quite reach. The Sergeant was awake now, and he had a mission. The Vicar would provide the cover.

The first was the weapon: not the instrument of death, which was a chilling mystery, but the instrument of communication. The photocopier. He drew a mental map of his parish and the surrounding districts, populating it with potential locations. Libraries, council-run community centres, struggling small businesses, and, most disquietingly, churches. The thought that the poison of Rex’s words might have been printed within the walls of a place of sanctuary was a particular kind of sacrilege.

He turned to the section listing his parishioners, his finger tracing the names. He began to make a new list on a fresh sheet of paper, a list not for pastoral visits or Christmas cards, but for a watch. He marked down the names of the widows and widowers, the ones whose children had moved away, the ones he hadn't seen in the pews for a month or two. The list grew steadily, each name a small knot of fear in his gut. There were too many. He couldn’t be a guardian to them all. He had to find the source.

In a small, dusty office behind the vestry, St. Jude’s had its own relic, a hulking Minolta that whirred and groaned like a man on his deathbed. Arthur fed it a sheet of paper and printed a blank page. He held the copy next to Rex’s pamphlet, comparing them under the light of his angle-poise lamp. The toner smudge on his own machine was a consistent vertical line down the right-hand side. The pamphlet’s smudge was a blotchy cloud in the upper-left quadrant. It wasn’t a match. He felt a sliver of relief, quickly extinguished by the scale of the task ahead.

He spent the rest of the day on the telephone, his voice a smooth, clerical balm that masked his true intent. He called the vicars, priests, and ministers of every church within a two-mile radius. His cover story was simple and believable: the Minolta was finally giving up the ghost and he was looking to see what machines other parishes used, perhaps even to buy a second-hand one if they were upgrading. The conversations were a slow trawl through a sea of mundane detail, but Arthur was patient. He listened to complaints about paper jams, expensive toner, and service contracts, and with each call, he mentally crossed another location off his list.

It was his fifth call, to the young Methodist minister at the Lockwood Chapel, that snagged his attention. The minister, barely out of theological college, was full of bright-eyed despair about the state of his inherited office equipment. "We've got this absolute beast, Arthur," he lamented. "An old Canon NP-6030. Pre-ark, I think. It works, mostly, but it leaves these awful grey smudges on everything, like a dirty thumbprint in the top corner. The community groups who rent the hall are always complaining." A dirty thumbprint in the top corner. The description was so precise, so evocative of the smear on the pamphlet, that the Sergeant in Arthur’s head sat bolt upright. He kept his voice even. "An old Canon, you say? We might be interested in taking it off your hands for parts, if you ever get rid." He thanked the young man, rang off, and stared at the receiver, a new and terrible certainty hardening within him.

With a potential location for the printer identified, his thoughts turned again to the flock. The list of vulnerable parishioners lay on his desk, a roll call of the forgotten. He couldn't just wait for Rex to choose his next target. He had to be a shepherd, a sentry. He scanned the names and his eyes landed on one: Elias Thorne. A retired Classics professor from the university, an atheist who only came to church for the Christmas carols and the architecture. Elias was eighty-nine, lived alone in a large, decaying Victorian house crammed with books, and was possessed of a tongue sharp enough to flay skin. He was fiercely, proudly independent. He was, in Rex's hateful taxonomy, the very definition of clutter.

Arthur grabbed his jacket. The rain had momentarily eased, leaving the air thick and damp. He walked the half-mile to Elias's house, a tall, soot-stained villa set back from the road behind a rampant laurel hedge. The gate groaned on its hinges. Books were visible in every window, stacked in precarious towers. He rang the bell and waited, hearing the slow, shuffling footsteps approach from within. The door opened a few inches, held by a chain, and a pair of piercing blue eyes peered out from a deeply lined face.

"Hamerton," Elias said, his voice a dry rasp. "Come to save my soul again? I've told you, it's not for sale, and its warranty expired sometime during the Attlee government."

"Just checking in, Elias," Arthur said gently. "I was passing. May I come in?"

The old man hesitated, then sighed and slid the chain free. "Oh, very well. But if you mention the Holy Spirit, you're buying the next bottle of sherry." The house smelled of paper, dust, and stewed tea. Every surface was buried under a landslide of books and academic journals. It was the epitome of clutter, but to Arthur, it looked like the bastion of a formidable mind. They sat in the drawing-room, surrounded by towers of learning. Arthur kept the conversation light, but his eyes were busy, noting the flimsy lock on the back door, the ground-floor windows that wouldn't close properly. Elias, for all his intellectual firepower, was physically frail, his hands trembling as he poured the sherry he'd ironically offered. He was a lion in winter, magnificent but exposed. As Arthur left, walking back out into the gathering gloom, the weight of his self-imposed responsibility settled more heavily on his shoulders. He had a potential source. He had a list of targets. He was no longer just a vicar. He was a watchman on the walls of a city under silent siege.The night offered no respite. Arthur sat in the dark of the vestry, the only light a pale wash from the streetlamp filtering through the high arched window, turning the falling rain to silver threads. Sleep was a country he could no longer visit. His mind, a restless engine, kept returning to the two fronts of his private war: the smudged pamphlet and the list of vulnerable names on his desk. Each name was a potential Agnes Gable, a life that could be extinguished with the brutal finality of a boot on a beetle. The silence of the church, usually a balm, felt accusatory. It was a space dedicated to a loving God, yet Arthur’s thoughts were of violence, tactics, and a man who called himself a king. The chalice sat on the corner of his desk, its polished surface reflecting nothing but the deep shadows, a dark mirror for his dark thoughts.

By dawn, inaction had become intolerable. The Sergeant asserted control, demanding a plan, a forward movement. The photocopier at the Lockwood Chapel was the only tangible lead he possessed. He needed a sample, an undeniable match. His pretext formed easily, a simple piece of parish business that would seem entirely natural. St. Jude’s was long overdue for a jumble sale to raise funds for the leaking vestry roof. He would need to print flyers. It was the perfect cover, a task that was both the Vicar's duty and the Sergeant's opportunity. He would walk into the lion’s den, not as a hunter, but as a sheep asking for a small favour.

Lockwood Chapel was a stark contrast to St. Jude’s. A red-brick Methodist hall from the 1960s, it had the functional, unadorned feel of a place built more for community than for contemplation. Its windows were large and square, its cross a simple, unadorned steel affair. The young minister, David, greeted him with a handshake that was both firm and slightly nervous, as if meeting a senior officer. He was a gangly youth with more zeal than experience, and he listened with sympathetic ears as Arthur explained his need to print a hundred flyers, lamenting the demise of his own ancient machine.

"Say no more, Arthur, say no more!" David said, leading him down a corridor that smelled of floor polish and instant coffee. "You can use our monster. The community groups are always in and out using it. Just be warned, it has a personality." He gestured to a small, cluttered office where a colossal beige photocopier, the Canon NP-6030, occupied a full corner of the room like a dormant rhino. "We have the writers’ group, the local history society, the tenants’ association… they all have a key to the hall and the office. It's a proper open house. Hence the state of this old beast."

The machine whirred to life with a groan of protest, its fans emitting a low, mournful howl. Arthur placed his master copy on the glass, a simple sheet advertising the jumble sale, and pressed the green button. The copier shuddered, lights flickered, and with a series of clunks and whirs, it spat a single sheet into the tray. Arthur picked it up, his heart thudding a slow, heavy rhythm against his ribs. He feigned a frown of annoyance. "Ah," he said, holding it up for David to see. "You weren't kidding about the smudges." There it was. In the top-left corner. A distinctive, cloudy grey smear, like a dirty thumbprint pressed onto the paper. It was a perfect match for the mark on Rex’s sermon. A cold certainty washed over Arthur. He was standing in the very room where that venom had been multiplied. Rex wasn't just some phantom; he was someone who used this hall. A writer. A local historian. A tenant. The list of suspects was at once narrowed and impossibly broad.

Leaving the chapel with a sheaf of now-useless flyers, the knowledge of the copier’s location burned in his mind. The threat was no longer abstract; it had a home. His focus shifted with renewed urgency to his other front: protection. He had to get to Elias Thorne. Not just to check on him, but to build a wall around him, a wall made of people. A Sergeant plans his defences, but a Vicar builds a community. Arthur decided to weave the two roles together. He would resurrect the Parish Visitors scheme, an old initiative that had fallen by the wayside, where members of the congregation would check in on the housebound and infirm.

He made two calls. The first was to Brenda Riley. Agnes's death had hollowed her out, but beneath the grief, Arthur sensed a new, hard resolve. When he proposed the visitors scheme, framing it as a way to ensure no one else suffered her mother's fate of being alone and undiscovered, her voice firmed. "Yes, Vicar. Of course. What do you need me to do?" His second call was to Eleanor Higgins, the churchwarden. A retired district nurse in her late sixties, Eleanor was a woman of formidable competence and zero sentimentality, built of the same stern stuff as the Pennine hills. She saw the practical sense of the plan immediately. He gave them their purpose, a righteous cause born from tragedy, carefully omitting the monstrous truth that spurred him on.

He met them in the chilly nave of St. Jude's, the three of them a small council of war beneath the gaze of the stone saints. He handed them a short list of names, with Elias Thorne at the top. "He's fiercely independent," Arthur warned them. "He'll resent anything that smells of charity. So don't make it a duty visit. Brenda, you like to bake. Drop off a slice of cake. Eleanor, you pass his house on your way to the shops. Offer to pick up his newspaper for him. Small things. Brief visits. But daily. I want to know, every single day, that a friendly face has seen him and that he is alright." They nodded, their faces grimly determined. They were his sentries now, his early warning system, cloaked in the simple kindness of the parish.

Returning to the vicarage later that afternoon, a sliver of hope pierced the gloom. He had a lead. He had a watch in place. It was a fragile defence against a monster, but it was a beginning. He walked up the path to the main church doors, intending to lock them for the evening. And then he saw it. It was fixed to the ancient, studded oak of the public noticeboard with a single, brutal thumbtack, pushed deep into the wood. Another cheap, grey pamphlet. It hadn't been slipped through his letterbox; it was displayed for all the world to see. He ripped it down, his fingers clumsy with a sudden dread. The title, in the same crude block capitals, read: `TIDYING UP: A PUBLIC NOTICE.` The text was shorter, sharper, dripping with contempt. "The authorities are blind and the shepherds are sleeping. The first beetle is crushed and they call it a fall. They mourn the clutter. But the work continues. The next to be put away is a man of many words but no substance. A dusty book that no one reads." Arthur’s blood ran cold. A dusty book. Elias. It was a death sentence, publicly declared. Rex wasn’t just killing; he was performing. And he was letting the world, and the Sergeant of St. Jude's, know exactly who was next. The race had begun.The flimsy paper felt like a burning coal in his hand. Panic was a useless indulgence, a luxury he could not afford. The Sergeant, cold and absolute, took command. The public notice wasn't just a threat; it was a timetable. It was a taunt aimed directly at him. *The shepherds are sleeping.* The words were a personal insult, a challenge thrown down in the most public of arenas. Arthur crumpled the pamphlet into a tight ball, the cheap paper resisting, then surrendering. He did not go to the police. Not yet. His first duty was not to the law, but to the sheep. He had to get to Elias.

He didn't run. The Sergeant had taught him that running attracts attention and exhausts you for the fight. He walked, his stride long and purposeful, his old tweed jacket flapping open in the damp wind. Every shadow seemed to deepen, every ginnel a potential ambush point. The short walk to Elias Thorne’s house stretched into an eternity of risk assessment. A white van parked halfway up the street, its side blank and anonymous. A man in a high-vis jacket walking away from the house. A window cleaner's ladder propped against a neighbour’s wall. Mundane details, now sinister possibilities. He saw the world through Rex’s eyes, a world of tools and opportunities for violence.

He hammered on the door, forgoing the bell. The sound echoed in the quiet street. After a long moment, Elias’s irritated voice floated through the wood. "I'm coming, I'm coming! The Goths are not at the gates!" The door opened on its chain, the old man’s face a mask of academic annoyance. "Hamerton, this is becoming a habit. If you're selling something, I'm not buying. If you're offering salvation, it’s still out of stock."

"Elias, you need to come with me," Arthur said, his voice low and urgent, devoid of its usual pastoral warmth. He put his hand on the door, a gesture that was both supportive and preventative. "There's been a problem at the vicarage. A burst pipe in the old wing. It’s a flood. I need a place to stay for a night or two, and I can't leave my books and papers. I was hoping I could impose on you." It was a lie, thin and poorly constructed, but it was the first weapon that came to hand.

Elias stared at him, his sharp blue eyes narrowing. He was a man who had spent a lifetime deconstructing texts, spotting fallacies, and he could smell the falsehood on Arthur. "A burst pipe? In this weather? Unlikely. You look like a man who's seen a ghost, Arthur, not a man worried about damp sermons. What is this really about?"

There was no time for subtlety. The Sergeant took a half-step forward, his presence filling the doorway. "Elias, I'm asking you to trust me. There is a danger to you. I can't explain everything right now, but your life is at risk. We need to leave this house. Now." The raw, unvarnished urgency in his voice, the complete absence of clerical softness, finally cut through the professor's intellectual defences. He saw not the vicar, but the Sergeant. He saw the weary watchfulness in Arthur's eyes flare into an unmistakable state of high alert.

"Very well," Elias said, his own voice losing its acerbic edge, replaced by a tremor of genuine fear. He fumbled with the chain. "Give me a moment to get my coat." As the old man shuffled back into the cluttered gloom of his house, Arthur stepped inside, pulling the door shut behind him. He didn't relax. He stood in the hall, his back to the wall, scanning the room, his ears straining for any sound other than the rustle of Elias’s coat and the ticking of a grandfather clock. He was inside the fortress, but the walls felt like paper.

With Elias finally bundled into his overcoat and clutching a worn leather satchel, Arthur hustled him out of the house and back towards the relative sanctuary of St. Jude's. He settled the bewildered professor in the vicarage's spare room, a small, cold chamber that smelled of mothballs. He poured him a large brandy, his own scarred hands surprisingly gentle. "Stay here, Elias. Lock the door. Don't open it for anyone but me. Do you understand?" Elias, his face pale, just nodded, the brandy glass rattling against his teeth.

With the lamb secured, Arthur went to confront the authorities. He walked into the police station, the crumpled pamphlet in one hand, the flyer from Lockwood Chapel in the other. He didn't wait to be announced. He walked straight past the front desk towards the CID offices. DI Miller, seeing him approach, emerged from his office with a face like thunder. "For God's sake, Arthur, I told you I was busy!"

"Agnes Gable was murdered, Frank," Arthur said, his voice flat and hard as slate. He smoothed the new pamphlet and the jumble sale flyer onto the corner of a nearby desk. "This proves it. The killer calls himself Rex. This first one was posted on my church door. It names his next target, a 'dusty book'. That's Elias Thorne, a retired professor in my parish." He pointed to the smudges on the two documents. "And this is where he prints them. Lockwood Methodist Chapel. Their photocopier leaves this exact mark. He has access. He's one of their community groups. He's planning to kill again, and he's telling us."

Miller stared at the papers, the colour draining from his face. The public notice, the specific threat, the physical evidence of the photocopier—it was too much to dismiss. The easy explanation of Accidental Death had just collapsed, threatening to bury him in an avalanche of negligence and bad press. The ghoul had become a real, taunting predator. "Right," he said, the word clipped, angry. He snatched up the papers. "Get a uniform to Thorne's house. Full protection. Now!" he barked at a passing detective.

"He's not there," Arthur said calmly. "He's with me. At the vicarage." Miller stared at him, a flicker of something—respect, perhaps, or just sheer astonishment—in his eyes. The vicar had run his own protection detail. "I want a list of every person with a key to that chapel, Frank. Every member of every group that meets there. The writers' group, the history society, all of them. He's in there somewhere. He's hiding in plain sight."

The rest of the day was a blur of police procedure. Miller, galvanised into grudging action, despatched officers. The cogs of a major investigation began to turn, slowly and with a great deal of groaning. But Arthur knew Rex had a head start. The killer had been moving while the police were sleeping. He couldn't afford to wait for them to catch up. That evening, leaving Elias in the care of a young, nervous-looking PC stationed in the vicarage hall, Arthur returned to Lockwood Chapel. The rain had started again, washing the grimy streets in a slick, oily sheen. The chapel was dark, locked up for the night, but a single light burned in a small office at the side of the building.

Arthur knocked. After a moment, the door was unlocked by a man in a grey caretaker's overall. He was a wiry, stooped man in his late fifties, with a face that seemed perpetually apologetic and watery, resentful eyes. "Can I help you?" he asked, his voice a low mumble.

"I'm sorry to bother you so late," Arthur said, employing his most benign vicar-smile. "I'm Arthur Hamerton, from St. Jude's. I was here earlier using your photocopier. I think I may have left a folder of papers in the office."

The caretaker, whose name badge read 'Colin', grunted and let him in. "Always leaving things, you lot," he muttered, shuffling back towards the office where the hulking Canon copier stood silent. "Treat the place like their own." The office was tidy now, the clutter cleared away. Colin's work. As Arthur feigned a search, he engaged the man in conversation, asking about the various groups that used the hall. Colin was a font of low-grade bitterness, complaining about the writers who left biscuit crumbs and the history buffs who argued over the heating.

"They don't see me," he said, wiping a clean surface with a dirty rag. "I'm just part of the furniture. The one who cleans up their mess. The one who tidies everything away." The phrase snagged in Arthur’s mind. *I have come to tidy.* Colin gestured to a stack of newsletters on a shelf. "History society. Full of old windbags talking about the war and the wool trade. All clutter, if you ask me. Just dust and memories." Arthur’s gaze fell upon the membership list for the history society, sitting right there on the desk, beside Colin's neatly arranged cleaning supplies. His blood ran cold. *Dusty book... dust and memories.* Colin, the invisible man, the tidier, the one who saw the elderly as clutter. Arthur looked at the caretaker’s watery eyes and saw, for a flicker of a second, the cold, hard certainty of a king surveying his untidy kingdom. He had found his suspect.The air in the small office became thick, unbreathable. Arthur looked at Colin, at the stoop of his shoulders, the listless way he held the cleaning rag, and tried to reconcile that image with the monstrous arrogance of Rex. But the resentment in the man’s watery eyes was a cold, hard thing. It was the deep, patient bitterness of a man who has spent a lifetime being overlooked. A man who tidies away the mess of others and feels his own life is just as disposable. Arthur felt a chill that had nothing to do with the damp night. He was standing in the presence of a profound, and murderous, vanity.

“Ah, here we are,” Arthur said, his voice a note or two higher than usual. He pulled a random leaflet from a pile on a side table, folding it and tucking it into his pocket as if it were the most important document in the world. “Silly of me. Must be getting as forgetful as some of my flock.” He gave Colin a brief, tight smile that felt like a grimace. “Thank you for your time, Colin. You keep this place wonderfully neat.” The compliment was a risk, a subtle probe, but Colin’s expression didn't change. He just grunted, his gaze already drifting towards a scuff mark on the linoleum. He was already back to his tidying, the vicar already forgotten. Arthur backed out of the office and let himself out into the rain, the lock clicking shut behind him with a sound of chilling finality. He had been in the killer's lair, had spoken to him, and had walked away.

He didn't go straight back to the vicarage. He walked to a red telephone box at the end of the street, the air inside thick with the ghosts of a thousand stale conversations. He fed coins into the slot and dialled Miller’s direct line, bypassing the front desk. The detective answered on the third ring, his voice frayed with exhaustion. “Miller.”

“Frank, it’s Arthur. I know who he is.”

A weary sigh came down the line. “Arthur, we’re running checks on the membership lists you gave me. We have a team at the chapel. Let us do our jobs.”

“It’s the caretaker,” Arthur said, ignoring the dismissal. “A man named Colin. He works there. He talks about the members as ‘clutter’. He talks about ‘tidying’. He’s the one, Frank. He’s the invisible man who sees everything and resents it all.”

There was a pause. Arthur could picture Miller pinching the bridge of his nose. “The cleaner? Arthur, come on. The language in those pamphlets, the historical references… it doesn’t fit a caretaker. We’re looking at the history society members, the academics. Someone with a grudge and a thesaurus. A cleaner doesn’t write a manifesto.”

“You’re looking for the wrong kind of intelligence,” Arthur shot back, the Sergeant’s impatience sharpening his tone. “This isn’t about education, it’s about obsession. He has the access, he has the motive, and he fits the profile of a man who feels powerless and wants to become God. Look at him, Frank. For God’s sake, just look at him properly.”

“We’ll talk to him, Arthur. He’s on the list,” Miller said, but his voice was placating, unconvinced. “Now go home. You’ve done enough. You have a parishioner under your roof and a police guard on your door. Let us handle it from here.” The line went dead. Arthur stood for a moment, the receiver buzzing in his ear like an angry insect. Miller was following the evidence, but he couldn't see the man. He was looking for a monster with a high IQ, not a monster with a set of keys and a lifetime of bitterness. Arthur knew, with a dreadful certainty, that Colin would slip right through the net of official procedure.

Back at the vicarage, the sight of the uniformed PC reading a newspaper in his hallway was both a comfort and a frustration. He was a symbol of protection, but also of the slow, methodical process that Arthur feared would be too late. He checked on Elias, who had fallen into a brandy-fueled sleep, his book-filled satchel clutched to his chest like a teddy bear. Seeing the old man’s vulnerability, the sheer fragility of him, hardened Arthur’s resolve. He couldn’t wait for Miller. He had to give the police a reason to look past Colin’s overalls. He had to find the weapon.

In the cold silence of his study, he spread a fresh sheet of paper on his desk. On it, he drew four small squares in a rectangular pattern. The marks on Agnes’s floor. The instrument was heavy, stable, and had four feet. Rex had said, *I am the boot. I am the gravity they forgot to fear. I pressed her.* It was a press. A deliberate, mechanical action. Arthur’s mind, trained to think in terms of logistics and equipment, scrolled through possibilities. It was too specific for a random object. It had to be something designed for the application of immense, even pressure. He went to his own small library of local history books, books that Colin’s counterpart in the history society might read. He pulled down a volume on the industrial heritage of the West Riding. He saw pictures of the great steam-powered presses in the wool mills, behemoths of iron and brass. Too big. Impossible to move. Then he found a smaller chapter, on ancillary trades. Printing. Bookbinding. And there it was. A photograph of a Victorian bookbinder’s workshop. In the centre of the room was a cast-iron nipping press. It was used to compress sewn pages before the cover was applied. It was squat, immensely heavy, and operated by a large, threaded screw. And its solid iron base rested on four square feet. Arthur stared at the picture, the black and white image coalescing with the bloody tableau in Agnes’s lounge. He felt a wave of nausea. Colin didn't just have access to a photocopier. A man who cared for an old community hall, a man who cleared out its forgotten corners, might just have access to its forgotten relics.

Action was the only antidote to the horror. He waited until well after midnight, when the PC in the hall had been replaced by a new one, and the rhythm of the house had settled into the deep quiet of the early hours. He shrugged on a dark raincoat over his clerical shirt, the black fabric a fitting habit for his grim purpose. He slipped out of the vicarage's back door, a shadow moving through the sleeping town. The rain had finally stopped, and the moon, a pale sliver, cast a weak, watery light on the wet slate roofs. Lockwood Chapel was a dark mass against the sky. Arthur circled it, the Sergeant assessing its defences. The main doors were solid, but the office window, he had noted earlier, had a faulty catch. It was an old sash window, its wood swollen with a century of damp. He took a thin metal ruler from his pocket – a tool for measuring hymn book margins, he’d have claimed, though its true purpose was more versatile. He worked it into the gap, applying steady pressure to the catch. After a long, tense minute, it gave with a soft click that sounded like a gunshot in the silence. He slid the window up, hoisted himself over the sill, and dropped silently into the caretaker's office.

He didn't turn on the light. He used a small penlight, its beam a nervous white blade cutting through the darkness. The office was as Colin had left it, unnaturally tidy. On the wall was a key-box. One of the labels read 'Basement'. Arthur took the key. The door to the basement was at the end of the main corridor. The lock turned smoothly. He opened the door and was met with a wave of cold, subterranean air, thick with the smell of damp earth and coal dust. The stairs were stone, worn into shallow bowls by decades of use. The beam of his torch danced over piles of broken chairs, stacks of old hymn books with broken spines, the detritus of a hundred jumble sales. Clutter. Colin’s kingdom of discarded things.

He moved deeper into the labyrinthine space, his footsteps muffled by the layer of dust. In the furthest corner, behind a stack of rotting stage flats from some long-forgotten Christmas pageant, he saw the edge of a tarpaulin. It was covering a large, awkwardly shaped object. His heart hammered against his ribs. He pulled back the canvas. It was a thing of brutalist Victorian simplicity. A huge, black, cast-iron frame, a screw mechanism thick as a man’s arm, and a flat upper plate, or platen, a foot and a half square. A nipping press. Its base was a single, solid casting with four square feet. Arthur knelt, his torch beam trembling. The sheer, functional ugliness of the thing was terrifying. It was an instrument of creation, of binding words together, turned into an instrument of annihilation. He ran the beam of light over the flat, greasy surface of the lower plate. There, caught in a smear of old oil, was a single, tiny thread of dark red wool. The colour of the cardigan Agnes Gable had been wearing when he had conducted her funeral. He had found Rex’s boot.The sight of the red thread, a tiny fleck of carmine against the greasy iron, was the final, damming comma in Rex’s hateful sermon. It was proof. Tangible, terrible proof. For a long moment, Arthur simply knelt in the dust, the beam of his torch fixed on that single fibre. He felt a profound, sickening sense of violation, not just for the act of murder, but for the corruption of the object itself. This press was a tool of knowledge, of preservation, designed to bind stories together. In Colin’s hands, it had become a tool to unmake them, to crush a life back into its elemental silence. The Sergeant took over, his mind overriding the Vicar’s horror. He catalogued the scene with a cold, internal precision: the dimensions of the press, its position in the corner, the scuff marks on the floor where it had been dragged, the tell-tale thread. He fought the urge to pocket the evidence, to take the thread. His entry was illegal; the fruit of this poisonous tree would be inadmissible, thrown out of court by any competent lawyer. Colin would walk free. He had to leave it all, undisturbed, a tableau for untainted eyes. With a slow, deliberate movement, he pulled the tarpaulin back over the press, shrouding the monstrous thing once more in darkness and dust.

His retreat was the reverse of his infiltration, a masterclass in silent movement. He locked the basement door, his fingers deft and sure, and hung the key back in its box, aligning it perfectly with the others. In the office, he paused, his gaze sweeping the tidy, anonymous space. It was the perfect lair for a man like Colin, a space he could control utterly, a kingdom of neatness built on a foundation of rage. He slid the window open, hoisted himself out, and used the metal ruler to gently nudge the sash back down until the faulty lock clicked, a sound barely audible above the frantic thumping of his own heart. He was outside, back in the damp Huddersfield night, a trespasser and a lawbreaker. The stone façade of the chapel seemed to watch him go, a silent, complicit witness. He felt no guilt for his crime, only the cold, heavy certainty of what he had to do next. The Vicar might wrestle with the morality of it later, but tonight, the Sergeant had a war to win.

The vicarage was quiet. The young PC in the hall looked up from a dog-eared thriller and gave him a questioning look. Arthur simply nodded, offering a weary smile. “Just needed some air. Long night.” He went through the motions of locking the door, his mind a thousand miles away, plotting his next assault. He went to his study, the familiar scent of beeswax and old paper doing nothing to soothe him. He poured a small measure of whisky, the fiery liquid a stark contrast to the cold dread that had settled in his bones. He had the weapon. He had the killer. But he was holding a hand of cards that he couldn't legally play. He looked at the telephone, the stern black Bakelite thing that had started this all. He had to force Miller’s hand. He had to make the DI look, without revealing how he knew where to point him.

He picked up the receiver, his knuckles white. He dialled the direct line, and when Miller’s sleep-deprived voice answered, Arthur spoke with a cold, clipped authority that was pure Sergeant. "Frank, you need to get a search warrant for the basement of the Lockwood Methodist Chapel. Now." He didn't wait for a response. "The murder weapon is there. It's a Victorian-era cast-iron book press. A nipping press. It was used to compress Agnes Gable. The caretaker, Colin, has been hiding it there."

The explosion on the other end of the line was immediate and furious. "A book press? How in the hell would you know that, Arthur? Have you been there? If you've contaminated a crime scene..."

"I have a source," Arthur cut in, his voice like ice. The lie came easily, a necessary sin to save a life. "Someone who uses the community hall. They're terrified of Colin. They saw him cleaning the thing late one night. They're an amateur historian, they knew what it was. They came to me because they were afraid to go to the police. They trust the cloth more than the badge, Frank. It happens." He let that sink in, a subtle jab at Miller’s earlier dismissal. He pressed his advantage. "Check your forensic reports for the marks on Agnes's floor. Then check the industrial archives for a press of that type. The footprint will match. Colin's hiding it in the basement, under a tarpaulin, in the far corner. My source was very specific."

There was a long, charged silence on the line. Arthur could almost hear the gears turning in the detective's mind – the anger at being manipulated, the professional risk of ignoring such a specific tip, the dawning, awful possibility that the vicar was right. The details were too precise for a guess. A book press. Under a tarpaulin. In the corner. It was a picture painted in undeniable colours. "If you don't act on this, Frank, and Colin kills Elias Thorne, the questions that will be asked won't be directed at me," Arthur added, his voice dropping to a near whisper. "My source is waiting. The press is waiting. And so is Rex."

The sigh that came from Miller was not one of weariness, but of reluctant surrender. The sound of a man being checkmated. "Stay where you are, Arthur. Do not leave the vicarage. Do not speak to anyone. Is that understood?" The tone was flat, devoid of any warmth, the command of a police officer, not a colleague. The line went dead. Arthur replaced the receiver, his hand trembling slightly, the adrenaline of the confrontation beginning to ebb. He had thrown his grenade. Now he could only wait for the blast.

He couldn't sit. He went to the tall vestry window that overlooked the street, a vantage point he had occupied so many times for contemplation. Now, it was a watchtower. The minutes stretched into an hour. The town slept on, ignorant of the silent war being waged in its midst. Then, he saw it. A dark Ford Mondeo, its headlights off, slid to a halt at the corner of the street by the chapel. A few minutes later, another car followed, parking further down. No flashing lights, no sirens. This was Miller’s quiet approach. They were taking him seriously. They were moving in. A profound, if temporary, relief washed over Arthur. He had done it. He had guided them to the truth.

Just as the first shadow of an officer detached itself from a car and moved towards the chapel's side entrance, the telephone on his desk jangled, the sound shrill and alien in the quiet room. Arthur’s first thought was that it was Miller, wanting to gloat or to curse him. He picked it up. "Hamerton." It was not Miller. It was Brenda Riley, and the tight, high-pitched panic in her voice was a sound he now knew all too well. "Arthur! I was worried about the Professor, I couldn't sleep. I just baked a scone, I thought maybe he'd like one... I've just come up the vicarage path. The front door is ajar! The policeman, the one in the hall... he's gone!" Arthur's blood turned to ice. "What do you mean, gone?" he demanded, his voice a harsh rasp. "He... he's just not there!" Brenda sobbed. "The chair is empty! Oh, God, Arthur... someone's left a can of polish and a cloth on the floor by the door. Like they were cleaning." A can of polish. A cloth. Colin’s tools. His calling card. He had drawn the guard away and slipped inside. Rex was not at the chapel. He was here. He was in the house.The world dissolved into a pinpoint of sound: Brenda's panicked voice, the words "polish" and "cloth," and the vast, roaring silence where a police guard was supposed to be. The Sergeant slammed the receiver back onto its cradle without a word, the plastic cracking under the force. The calculated victory of a moment ago, the intellectual checkmate played over the phone, was a child's game. The wolf was not in the pen; it was in the nursery.

He moved with a speed that belied his years, a lethal economy of motion that was all Sergeant. There was no time for a weapon from the world outside, only what was at hand. His eyes fell on the silver chalice on his desk, his one indulgence, heavy and pure. He snatched it up, its familiar weight a cold, solid promise in his palm. It was a cup of life, of communion. Tonight, it would be a cudgel. He was out of the study and taking the narrow vicarage stairs two at a time, the consecrated silver held low and ready.

The spare room door was ajar, just as Brenda had said. He pushed it open. The room was cold, the window slightly open to the night air. The bed was made, the pillow plumped, the spare blanket folded neatly at its foot. Elias was gone. The room hadn't been fought in; it had been tidied. Colin had not just taken the professor; he had erased him, smoothing over the messy evidence of his presence. A wave of nausea and fury rose in Arthur’s throat. This was the ultimate expression of Colin’s sickness: to neaten a man out of existence.

Then he heard it. Not a cry, but a soft, rhythmic scraping from the direction of the main church, through the connecting door from the vicarage hallway. It was the sound of something heavy being dragged across the ancient flagstones. He was taking him into the sanctuary. The sheer, blasphemous arrogance of it stole Arthur’s breath. Colin wasn't just committing murder; he was performing a sacrament of his own devising, a baptism of violence at the very heart of Arthur’s world.

He pushed through the vestry door into the cavernous dark of St. Jude's. The only light was the ambient glow from the Huddersfield streetlamps, filtered through the high stained-glass windows, painting the stone pillars and carved pews in bruised shades of purple and blood red. And there, at the far end of the nave, was the tableau. Colin, a stooped, wiry silhouette, was dragging the bound and gagged form of Elias Thorne towards the chancel steps. He was taking him to the altar.

"Colin," Arthur's voice was not a shout, but a low, carrying command that cut through the silence. It echoed in the vast space, the voice of the Sergeant, not the Vicar. Colin stopped. He turned slowly, his face a pale oval in the gloom. He was not panicked or frenzied. His expression, what Arthur could see of it, was one of weary annoyance, the look of a man interrupted in the middle of a necessary, if unpleasant, chore.

When Arthur finally returned to the vicarage in the cold, grey light of pre-dawn, the silence was absolute. The police were gone. The house felt violated, its peace broken. He must have slept, for he was woken by a gentle tapping on the study door. Sunlight, clear and golden, was streaming through the window, illuminating the dust motes dancing in the air. A week later, DI Miller appeared at the vestry door. He was holding a cardboard box. "It's been processed," he said, placing the box on Arthur’s desk. "The dents are part of the official record now." After the detective had gone, Arthur carried the chalice to his polishing table. He sat for a long time, just looking at it. The gash in its side was a scar, a memory of a terrible night. It was ugly, and it was true. It was a wound taken in the defence of his flock. He picked up his soft cloth, dipped it in the polish, and began to work. He didn't try to rub out the dent. He polished the smooth, unblemished surfaces, bringing them to a high, clear shine. He polished right up to the edges of the wound, accepting its presence, integrating it into the whole. He held it up, and the silver reflected his face, no longer wide-angled and distorted, but clear. The face of a clergyman, holding a Sergeant's scarred and sacred cup.The autumn that followed the summer of Rex was a season of quiet mending. The town, and the church with it, began to heal, its collective trauma scabbing over into a grim local legend to be told on dark nights. For Arthur Hamerton, however, the mending was a more complicated affair. He went about his duties, his voice a calm anchor in the Sunday service, his presence a comforting weight in the homes of the sick and lonely. But the Sergeant was no longer buried. He was an integrated part of him, a constant, low-level hum of vigilance beneath the surface of the Vicar’s placid exterior. He saw his parish not just as a flock to be tended, but as a territory to be watched.

His relationship with Elias Thorne deepened into a strange and comfortable friendship, a weekly chess game played out in the vicarage study amidst the scent of beeswax and the professor’s expensive pipe tobacco. They rarely spoke of the night Colin Gable had tried to tidy the old man away, but it was a constant, unspoken presence between them, the foundation of their bond. Elias, with his fierce intellect and newfound appreciation for ‘robust pastoral care’, became Arthur’s sounding board, a secular confessor who could dissect a problem with the clean precision of a logician. It was Elias who, one Tuesday evening as the rain lashed against the windows, noticed the change in his friend. "You are restless, Arthur," he observed, moving his knight into a threatening position. "You have the look of a soldier expecting an ambush in peacetime. The war is over. The dragon is slain." Arthur looked from the chessboard to the scarred chalice, which now sat permanently on his mantelpiece, its dent catching the lamplight. "Wars are never over, Elias," he said quietly. "They just change their shape."

The new shape arrived not with a bang, but with a tearful, hesitant phone call. It was a young woman named Sarah Nelson. He didn't know her; she wasn't a parishioner. Her voice was thin and frayed with sleeplessness. She and her husband, Mark, had bought a house in the new Pennine View development, a controversial estate of neat, identical boxes built on the flattened remains of the old Blackwood Mill. They were, she whispered, desperate. Their new dream home had become a place of terror. They believed it was haunted. Arthur had dealt with ‘hauntings’ before. They were almost always the product of faulty wiring, old pipes, or the subtle acoustics of a settling house amplified by loneliness and suggestion. He agreed to visit the next day, his mind already preparing the gentle, rational explanations and the comforting words of a blessing.

The Pennine View estate was an alien landscape on the edge of Huddersfield’s familiar, grimy grandeur. The houses were pale brick and plastic, the roads were pristine blacktop, and the small patches of lawn were unnervingly green. It lacked the honest wear and tear of the town; it smelled of plaster dust and fresh paint, not of damp stone and history.
