This was different. This was a cold, calculating emptiness that saw people as numbers on a balance sheet. He turned and walked out, but as he did, he noticed something. On the corner of Vincent’s desk, tucked under a paperweight, was a small, folded betting slip. Arthur's eyes, trained to notice the details, caught the name of a horse and a race time. It was a small, insignificant detail. But the Sergeant knew that in every war, victory was built on the accumulation of small, insignificant details. He had found a new kind of monster, one who couldn't be fought with a chalice or a chokehold. This battle wouldn't be won in the darkness of a cellar or a culvert. It would have to be won in the light, and he knew, with a grim and weary certainty, that it would be the most difficult fight of his life.He left the sterile chill of the office and descended the narrow, linoleum-covered stairs, the faint, tinny chime of the betting shop door a punctuation mark to his retreat. The encounter had left him with a familiar sense of righteous anger, but also a new and unsettling feeling of impotence. Rex and Finch were monsters of passion, their evil a legible, if terrifying, text. Vincent was a different language entirely, a bland corporate prose that masked a deep and structural violence. How did a man of God fight a spreadsheet? How did a Sergeant lay siege to a balance sheet? The law that Vincent operated under was a jungle of fine print and loopholes, a terrain where men like him thrived and women like Dorothy Meadows were lost.

That evening, the chessboard sat between him and Elias, a silent battlefield that mirrored the one in Arthur's mind. He laid out the problem of Mr. Vincent, not as a cry for help, but as a tactical problem he couldn’t yet solve. "He is insulated by a veneer of legality, Elias," Arthur said, moving his queen into a defensive position. "He hides behind contracts and compliance. Dorothy signed a paper, and in the eyes of the world, that is the end of the matter. He has built a fortress of paperwork." Elias took a long, slow draw on his pipe, his eyes narrowed in concentration. "Then you are looking at the wrong battlefield, Arthur. You are trying to assault the fortress wall when there is, perhaps, a postern gate. A man who builds his life on the exploitation of others' weaknesses invariably has a foundational weakness of his own. His arrogance is his blind spot. You said you saw a betting slip."

"A small detail," Arthur conceded. "It could mean nothing. A flutter on the Grand National." "Or," Elias countered, his voice a dry rasp, "it could mean everything. Greed is a hydra, my friend. A man greedy enough to prey on pensioners is often greedy enough to believe he can outwit the laws of probability. A loan shark with a gambling habit is a snake eating its own tail. It is a classic, almost literary, flaw. You cannot attack his business, which is his strength. You must attack his vice, which is his weakness." The professor’s words cut through Arthur’s frustration, re-framing the problem not as a moral outrage but as a strategic puzzle. He had to stop thinking like a Vicar, who sees a sinner to be saved, and start thinking like a Sergeant, who sees an enemy with a supply line that can be cut.

The following afternoon, Arthur did something he had not done in his thirty years of ministry. He pushed open the door of a betting shop. The atmosphere hit him first: a fug of stale cigarette smoke, desperation, and cheap coffee. A handful of men, their faces grey with the Huddersfield damp and the pallor of dashed hopes, stood staring at a bank of television screens showing brightly-coloured silks flashing around a distant racecourse. The drone of a commentator’s voice was the room’s only liturgy. Arthur’s clerical collar felt like a theatrical costume, drawing a few curious, resentful glances. He ignored them, stepping over a carpet stained with decades of lost wagers, and took up a position near the back, feigning interest in a racing form he had picked up from the counter. He was not there to bet. He was there to listen. He was an anthropologist in a strange and hostile jungle.

He waited for almost an hour, a silent, black-clad statue in a sea of fidgeting anxiety. Men came and went, their brief flurries of hope or despair washing over him. He heard nothing of consequence. He was about to leave, concluding that Elias's theory was merely literary, when two men at the counter next to him began to talk. Their voices were low, conspiratorial. "See Vincent was in earlier?" one said, a wiry man with a gambler’s tic in his eye. "Big bet on a three-legged nag at Kempton. Again." The other man, heavier and more morose, snorted. "Flash git. Thinks he's some kind of big shot, but he's sweating. I heard from Stevie P. that he's into the Mancunians for a heavy whack. That's not the kind of debt you pay off in instalments." The first man shuddered. "The Mancunians? Christ. Rather owe the devil. At least he'd give you a receipt." The conversation moved on, but Arthur had heard enough. The Mancunians. A faceless, threatening name that spoke of a different league of predator, a world far from the shabby respectability of Pennine Mutual Finance. Vincent was not the spider at the centre of the web. He was just a struggling fly, frantically trying to suck the life from smaller insects before a much bigger spider came for him.

He left the shop, his heart beating a slow, steady rhythm of grim purpose. He now had the map to Vincent’s postern gate. He had his weakness, and he had the name of the bigger fear that haunted him. He could not go to the police; he had no proof, only overheard whispers in a betting shop. He could not confront Vincent himself; the man would simply lie and deny. But he could introduce one fear to another. He could write a new name in Vincent's ledger, the name of an enemy he truly dreaded. Back in the sanctuary of his study, the plan formed, simple and brutal in its elegance. It was a plan that required no violence, no breaking and entering, no law-breaking on his own part. It required only a single, anonymous act of communication. It was a weapon made of information, delivered with the cold precision of an assassin’s bullet. He sat down at his desk and pulled a fresh sheet of paper from a drawer. He would not use a photocopier this time. He took a pen, and in a deliberately crude, block-capital script that was nothing like his own, he began to write. This was not a sermon. It was a poison-pen letter, designed to pit one monster against another, and Arthur Hamerton, the Shepherd of St. Jude's, wrote it without a flicker of hesitation.He sat at his desk not as a vicar composing a sermon, but as a field agent drafting a communiqué. The paper was cheap, lined foolscap torn from a notepad, the kind of paper that held no memory and offered no clues. The pen was a common blue biro. He wrote with his left hand, forcing his script into a crude, ugly block-print, the letters leaning against each other like tired, drunken soldiers. The message was stripped of all emotion, a cold, dry pellet of information. It was not a plea for justice; it was a business tip for predators. He addressed it to no one in particular, trusting that it would find its intended audience in the ecosystem of fear he was about to disturb. The note was brutally simple, a masterpiece of targeted poison.

"A FRIENDLY WORD. YOU SHOULD ASK YOUR CLIENT VINCENT, IN HUDDERSFIELD, ABOUT HIS OTHER BUSINESS. PENNINE MUTUAL FINANCE, ABOVE THE CORAL ON KING STREET. HE HAS A PRIVATE LOAN BOOK WORTH TENS OF THOUSANDS, CASH IN HAND, FROM OLD PEOPLE AND THE DESPERATE. HE'S NOT PAYING HIS DEBTS TO YOU BECAUSE HE'S SPENDING THEIR PENSION MONEY ON HORSES. HE IS LAUGHING AT YOU."

He read it over once, the words seeming alien and venomous on the page. 'He is laughing at you.' That was the masterstroke, the drop of acid designed to dissolve any loyalty or patience. It was a lie, of course. Vincent wasn't laughing; he was drowning. But the Mancunians would not care about the truth, only about the insult. Arthur folded the single sheet of paper and slid it into a plain white envelope. He did not write an address. He would deliver this message to its world in person.

The next day was a wash of grey, persistent drizzle, a day for staying indoors. Arthur, however, drove his old Escort west, over the bleak, beautiful spine of the Pennines, leaving the familiar valleys of his parish behind. Manchester was a different entity, a sprawling, energetic metropolis whose indifference felt like a form of camouflage. Following the intelligence he had gathered in the betting shop, he found the pub in Ancoats. It was a hard-looking place of red brick and grimy windows, a fortress of stale beer and quiet menace. He did not go in. To step inside would be to cross a line, to enter the battlefield himself. His role was to be the anonymous intelligence officer, not the frontline soldier. He parked a street away, walked to a small, red postbox gleaming with rain, and dropped the blank white envelope into its dark mouth. The act was small, utterly anticlimactic. The letter vanished with a soft, papery sigh. He had launched his missile. He turned and walked back to his car without looking back, the rain washing his face, feeling as if he had just committed a murder by mail.

The week that followed was a slow torture of normality. He went about his pastoral duties, his public life a serene counterpoint to the secret war he had just escalated. He visited Dorothy Meadows, who jumped at the sound of his knock and was a taut bundle of nerves throughout his visit. He sat with her, drank her weak tea, and spoke of faith, of resilience, of how light always overcomes the darkness. The words felt like a profound hypocrisy in his own mouth. He was comforting a sheep while knowing he had just directed a pack of wolves towards her tormentor. He felt a deep, spiritual vertigo, the chasm between the Vicar and the Sergeant now a vast, unbridgeable canyon. During this time, he found himself constantly drawn to the scarred chalice on his study mantelpiece. Its physical, honest wound was a comfort. That had been a fight of bone and sinew. This new fight was a thing of whispers and shadows, a battle fought with ink and motive, and it felt infinitely more corrupting.

The first sign that the stone had landed in the dark pond came a week to the day after his trip to Manchester. He was walking down King Street, on his way to visit a parishioner in the infirmary, when he glanced up at the window of Pennine Mutual Finance. The vertical blinds, usually angled to display Vincent’s sharp-suited form, were pulled tightly shut. It was a small thing, but it was a disruption in the pattern, a tell. The spider was no longer advertising his web. Two days later, the change was more pronounced. A clumsy, hand-written sign was taped to the street-level door. It said, simply, “CLOSED.” The bored-looking receptionist was gone. The shabby office was empty. A profound silence had fallen over the enterprise of Mr. Vincent.

Arthur felt no elation, only a cold, hollow sense of finality. He received his confirmation a few days after that, not from a sign or a whisper, but from a sighting. He was at the bus station, dropping off a box of donated books for a church in a neighbouring town, when he saw him. Vincent was huddled on a bench, a man stripped of all his predatory plumage. The slick suit and confident posture were gone, replaced by a cheap anorak and the hunched, furtive stance of a man expecting a blow from any direction. His handsome face was pale and unshaven, his eyes wide and constantly scanning the crowds, not for victims, but for hunters. He clutched a worn holdall to his chest like a shield. He looked like a man who had seen a ghost, a bigger, more terrifying ghost than any he had inflicted on his own clients. Arthur watched as Vincent boarded a grimy bus heading north, its destination somewhere anonymous and far away. He was a king dethroned, a predator turned prey, running for his life from a debt that could never be repaid. Arthur felt nothing. He had simply balanced an equation.

That night, Elias Thorne sat opposite him, the chessboard between them. Arthur had already told him that Dorothy Meadows’s problem had, in his words, “abruptly resolved itself.” The professor, whose intellect missed nothing and demanded no vulgar confessions, looked at him from across the board. “There is a story by Saki,” he said, his voice a dry murmur as he contemplated his next move, “in which a man rids his neighbour’s garden of an infestation of cats by the simple expedient of introducing a coyote. It is a clean, efficient, and thoroughly brutal solution.” He picked up his bishop, the carved ivory cool and precise in his old hand. “It seems you are moving beyond the simple cudgel, Arthur. You are learning the art of ecology. You are discovering how to manage the beasts of your jungle by introducing more fearsome beasts. A dangerous game.” He placed the bishop down, its new position a subtle but lethal threat to Arthur’s queen. "Be careful you do not become so adept at handling monsters that you forget you are a shepherd. Your move." Arthur looked down at the board, at his threatened queen and his fortified king. He had removed a blight from his parish without breaking a law or throwing a punch. He had won. And the cold, terrifying truth was, it had been remarkably easy.The victory over Vincent was a silent one, leaving no wreckage save for a hand-written "CLOSED" sign and the ghosts of bad debts that slowly evaporated from the lives of the vulnerable. For Dorothy Meadows, it was a miracle. She brought a small, slightly lopsided sponge cake to the vicarage, her eyes bright with a relief that had erased the lines of fear from her face. “It was your prayers, Vicar,” she said, her voice filled with a simple, unshakeable faith. “I knew the Lord wouldn’t forsake me. He sent that awful man packing.” Arthur accepted the cake and her thanks, the words of praise feeling like hot coals in his mouth. He had prayed, it was true. But he had also written a letter that had, in all likelihood, condemned a man to a life of terror, or worse. He had answered a prayer by summoning a demon. The gap between Dorothy’s gentle faith and his own brutal pragmatism had become a chasm of deceit, and he was standing on the wrong side of it.

Autumn bled into the first cold bite of winter. A hard frost silvered the cobbles of the ginnels and laid a brittle, white skin over the grass in the churchyard. Arthur tried to immerse himself in the familiar rhythms of his calling, to be the shepherd Elias had warned him he was in danger of forgetting. He organized the rota for the Christmas bazaar, mediated a simmering dispute between two factions of the bell-ringing society, and spent a long, damp afternoon on a ladder clearing sodden leaves from the vestry gutters. These were the small, unglamorous duties of a parish priest, the slow, patient work of holding a community together stitch by stitch. He willed it to be enough. He tried to push the cold, analytical mind of the Sergeant into dormancy, to silence the part of him that saw every closed door as a concealment and every new face as a potential threat.

“You are trying to put the sword back in its scabbard,” Elias observed one evening, as the fire in the study grate crackled against the howl of the wind outside. “But it has been drawn and tasted blood. It will not rest easy.” Arthur stared at the board, at the static, frozen war of the ivory pieces. “It was too easy, Elias,” he said, the confession costing him a great deal. “With Vincent. I wrote a few lines on a piece of paper, and a man’s life was dismantled. There was no confrontation, no risk. Just… administration. It felt unclean.” The professor nodded slowly, his expression unreadable. “You are discovering the true nature of power, Arthur. It is not the cudgel that is most effective, but the whisper. The well-placed word that turns an enemy’s strength against himself. You have learned that you can make the jungle curate itself. A formidable, and terrible, skill for a man in your profession.”

The new threat, when it came, did not knock on the door with a problem. It arrived as a piece of cheerful gossip, delivered by Brenda Riley as she helped fold parish newsletters in the chilly church hall. “Have you heard about that new church, Vicar?” she asked, her hands moving with brisk efficiency. “The one that’s opened up in the old MacIntyre’s warehouse down by the canal? It’s called ‘The Sanctuary of the Brighter Day’. My neighbour, Jean, she’s been going. She says it’s wonderful. Not like this, all cold stone and hymns you can’t sing,” she added, with a fond, apologetic glance around the hall. “It’s all modern music, and the pastor, he’s amazing. So full of life. Jean says you come out feeling like you could conquer the world.”

Arthur kept his expression neutral, a practiced mask of mild pastoral interest. “Oh, really? It’s always good to see people finding faith, wherever that may be.” But the Sergeant was awake, his senses pricking up at the details. A warehouse. Modern music. A charismatic pastor. It was a formula, an enterprise. He felt a familiar, cold stirring of suspicion. Faith, in Arthur’s experience, was a difficult, complicated, and often quiet affair. It was the endurance of the old stone in his church, the quiet flame of a candle in the darkness, the weary hope in a sickroom. It was rarely a product to be marketed with bright lights and a guarantee of feeling good. That evening, he looked up ‘The Sanctuary of the Brighter Day’ online. It had a slick, professional website filled with smiling, attractive people. There were videos of the pastor, a handsome, energetic man in his late thirties with a dazzlingly white smile, who introduced himself as Pastor John. He spoke with a passionate, well-rehearsed sincerity about casting off doubt, breaking the chains of negativity, and embracing the divine prosperity that was everyone’s birthright. The site also featured a prominent, easy-to-use ‘Donate’ button.

On a cold, clear Sunday evening, Arthur left his cassock in the wardrobe. He dressed in a simple dark jumper, nondescript trousers, and an old waterproof jacket, the collar pulled up. He was not the Vicar of St. Jude’s; he was just another face in the crowd. The warehouse was easy to find, its entrance marked by a huge, professionally printed banner and an almost overwhelming blaze of light that spilled out into the industrial twilight. Inside, the transformation was staggering. The vast, cavernous space, which should have smelled of old wool and machine oil, had been converted into a modern auditorium. A sophisticated lighting rig hung from the steel girders, casting pools of warm, coloured light. On a large stage at the far end, a band with electric guitars and a drum kit was playing an upbeat, anthemic song, the lyrics projected onto two huge screens. The place was packed, hundreds of people, many of them young, singing along with their hands in the air, their faces rapt with an ecstatic joy that felt both deeply genuine and faintly unsettling.

Then, Pastor John bounded onto the stage. He was even more compelling in person, a whirlwind of energy and charm. He moved like a rock star and spoke like a master salesman, his sermon a seamless blend of motivational speech, self-help jargon, and cherry-picked scripture. He talked about God’s desire for them to be successful, healthy, and wealthy. He told stories of people whose lives had been transformed, whose businesses had boomed, whose illnesses had vanished, all through the power of positive faith and ‘sowing a seed’ into the ministry. He brought a woman on stage who claimed her crippling debts had mysteriously vanished a week after making a large donation. The crowd roared its approval. Arthur stood near the back, a cold, still island in a sea of fervent emotion, and he felt a profound sense of dread. He was not watching a service; he was watching a masterfully executed performance. This was not a shepherd feeding his flock. This was a rancher, fattening his cattle. He saw the same predatory instinct he had seen in Vincent’s cold eyes, but this was infinitely more dangerous. Vincent had only wanted their money. Pastor John, with his dazzling smile and easy promises, was mining their very souls.

The rain in Huddersfield had a personality; a persistent, nagging misery that seeped not just into the mortar of the old wool mills but into the very bones of the people who walked the slick, cobbled ginnels. It wasn't a cleansing rain. It was a grey, mithered thing that clung to windows and made the world outside the pane a watercolour blur. Sergeant Arthur Hamerton, a title he no longer used but couldn't quite shed, watched it from the vestry window. It was a Tuesday. The scent of old wood, beeswax, and a faint, lingering dampness was the perpetual incense of St. Jude’s. Arthur preferred it to the cloying sweetness of the actual incense his predecessor had favoured. This scent was honest. It smelled of age, of endurance, of the slow, inevitable return of all things to the earth.

He was polishing the chalice, a simple silver cup that was his only real indulgence. His predecessor had also favoured a gilt monstrosity studded with chips of coloured glass, but Arthur had quietly retired it to a felt-lined box in the crypt. His own chalice was unadorned, heavy in his hands, its surface reflecting a distorted, wide-angled version of his face: a long, thinning face, bracketed by ears that seemed too large, and eyes that had settled into a permanent state of weary watchfulness. The face of a clergyman. But the hands polishing the silver were not a clergyman's hands. They were thick, the knuckles scarred, the grip sure and economical. The hands of a Sergeant. A Sergeant of the Church Army, a title that confused most of his parishioners and suited him just fine. It was a halfway house between two lives, a role that embraced both the sword and the word, though his sword these days was pastoral care and a belief in the fundamental decency of his flock. A belief the rain was always trying to erode.

The telephone, a stern black Bakelite thing on his desk, jangled with an abruptness that cut through the quiet hum of the rain. He picked it up, the cool plastic familiar against his ear.

"St. Jude's. Vicar Hamerton speaking." He never used 'Sergeant'. It felt like a boast.

"Arthur? It's... it's Brenda." The voice was thin, stretched tight with a panic that hadn't yet found the release of tears. Brenda Riley. Her mother, Agnes, was eighty-six, a cornerstone of the church’s knitting circle and a woman whose memory for town history was both a blessing and a curse.

"Brenda, what is it? Is everything alright?" He kept his voice low and even, a practised calm he’d spent years cultivating.

"It's Mum. She... she wasn't answering. The milk's still on the step from yesterday. I used my key, Arthur. I'm in the hall. Oh, God. The smell..." Her voice cracked, a dry, rasping sound. "There's something wrong. I can't... I can't make myself go into the lounge."

"Stay where you are, Brenda. Don't go any further. I'm coming right now." He put the receiver down without waiting for a reply, his movements suddenly precise, all languid contemplation gone. He shrugged on his old tweed jacket, its elbows patched with worn leather, and was out the vestry door in seconds, the rain hitting his face with a sudden, cold shock. He didn't bother with an umbrella. The rain was just a fact of life, like sin. You could try to shield yourself from it, but eventually, you were going to get wet.

Agnes Gable lived three streets away, in a row of stone-fronted terraces that clung to the hillside like stubborn limpets. The houses were respectable but tired, their small front gardens tidy, their windows veiled with net curtains. A police car was already parked clumsily on the pavement outside number seventeen, its blue light rotating with a silent, methodical rhythm that seemed obscene in the quiet, grey street. A small knot of neighbours stood on the opposite pavement, their faces pale and drawn, their umbrellas a cluster of black mushrooms. They nodded at Arthur as he passed, a collective, silent gesture of deference and dread. He was the vicar. His arrival made it official. This was a tragedy.

A uniformed constable, a lad so young his stubble looked like a faint pencil smudge, stood at the open door. He recognised Arthur and his expression softened with relief. "Vicar. Glad you're here. The daughter's in a right state."

"I'll see to her," Arthur said, stepping over the threshold. "Who's in charge?"

"DI Miller, sir. He's through there." The constable jerked his chin towards the lounge.

Brenda was slumped on the bottom step of the narrow staircase, her face buried in her hands. Arthur placed a hand on her shoulder. It was trembling violently. He said nothing, just stood there, his presence a solid, undemanding weight beside her. That was the first lesson he’d learned, long before the seminary. When there are no words, just be there. The silence was more honest.

After a moment, he walked past her to the open door of the lounge. The smell hit him then, coppery and sweet, the scent of a butcher’s shop left to warm in the sun. It was a smell he hadn't encountered in a decade, but his body remembered it instantly. His stomach tightened, a cold, hard knot.

The room was neat. Obsessively so. China dogs on the mantelpiece, lace doilies on the arms of the floral-patterned sofa, a family photograph from a wedding decades ago. And on the floor, by the hearth, lay Agnes Gable. DI Miller, a burly man whose suit was too tight across the shoulders, was crouched beside the body. He looked up as Arthur entered, his expression a mixture of professional courtesy and impatience.

"Arthur. Didn't expect to see you so soon."

"Brenda called me. She's one of mine, Frank. So was her mother." Arthur’s eyes were fixed on the scene. It was wrong. All wrong. Agnes was lying on her back, her limbs arranged at angles that were not just unnatural, but impossible for a simple fall. Her thin housecoat was soaked through with a dark stain that had spread across the Axminster carpet. But it was the compression that made Arthur's breath catch. Her torso... it was as if a great weight had been placed upon it. As if a car had driven over her. Her face, mercifully turned away from the door, was obscured, but the shape of her head was distorted, flattened against the floor in a way that spoke of immense, deliberate pressure.

"Nasty one," Miller said, standing up with a grunt and wiping his hands on a handkerchief. "Looks like she took a fall, hit her head on the fireplace fender. Must have been lying here a day or two."

Arthur didn't reply. His gaze drifted from Agnes to the floor around her. He saw the deep indentations in the worn linoleum, just beyond the edge of the rug. Four of them. Symmetrical. The marks of something heavy. Something with four square feet, put down and then lifted up again. He looked at the sturdy oak coffee table, the television on its stand. Nothing matched. Nothing in the room could have made those marks, or done... that.

"A fall?" Arthur finally said, his voice quiet. He looked at Miller, whose face was already settling into the easy explanation. The case filed, the paperwork completed. An accidental death. Non-suspicious.

"It happens, Arthur. They get frail. Bones like chalk." Miller clapped him on the shoulder. "Best go see to the daughter. We'll be done here soon."

Arthur nodded, his mind a thousand miles away. He backed out of the room, the image of those four indentations burned into his vision. He went and sat with Brenda, murmuring the useless, necessary platitudes that were the currency of his trade. But as he spoke of peace and God's mysterious ways, another part of him, the cold, analytical Sergeant, was turning over the facts. The impossible angles. The smell of overwhelming trauma. The four square marks on the floor. This wasn't a fall. This was an execution. A pressing. And the person who did it had brought the instrument with them, and taken it away.

A week passed. The rain came and went. The inquest was swift, the verdict recorded as Accidental Death, with a rider from the coroner about the dangers faced by the elderly living alone. Huddersfield sighed a collective, sorrowful sigh, and moved on. The knitting circle was smaller now. Arthur conducted the funeral. He spoke of Agnes’s warmth, her humour, her unwavering faith. He spoke of the Resurrection and the life to come. And all the while, he felt like a liar, because what had happened to Agnes Gable had nothing to do with God. It was something else entirely. Something ancient and brutal that had slouched into a tidy little terrace and left nothing but a stain on the carpet and four mysterious marks on the floor.

It was two days after the funeral that the first one arrived. It wasn't a letter. It was a pamphlet, the sort you might find slipped under your windscreen wiper, advertising a new takeaway or a political party. It was on cheap, grey paper, printed badly, the ink slightly smeared as if done on a faulty photocopier. It had been pushed through the vicarage letterbox along with a handful of circulars and a bill. Arthur almost threw it away. But the title, in thick, crude block capitals, stopped him cold.

A SHORT SERMON FOR THE SLOW.

He took it into his study, the chalice sitting half-polished on his desk, and smoothed it flat. The text was a single, dense block, without paragraphs or mercy. It was a tirade. A torrent of pure, undiluted hatred, written in a style that was both childish and terrifyingly articulate.

"The world is cluttered," it began. "Full of used things. Things that have had their day. Spindly-legged chairs waiting to break. Cracked cups. Rusting cars. And people. Oh, the people. The worst clutter of all. The wrinkled ones, the brittle-boned, the ones who smell of mothballs and regret. They are the dust of the world. They are the beetles scuttling in the dark, all shell and no substance. They take up space. They breathe our air. They tell their boring stories. Their time is UP. I have come to tidy. I have come to put things away. You saw the one in the neat little house? The old beetle? I am the boot. I am the gravity they forgot to fear. I pressed her back into the dust she came from. A mercy, really. A kindness. This is not a judgment. This is housekeeping. There will be more. The clutter must be cleared."

It wasn't signed with a name. Just a crude, spiky drawing at the bottom of the page. A shape that could have been a crown, or perhaps a set of jagged teeth. And beneath it, one word.

REX.

Arthur read it once. Then he read it again, a deep cold settling in his marrow that had nothing to do with the dampness of the old house. The boot. I pressed her. The words resonated with the horror in Agnes Gable's lounge, with the four square marks on the lino. This wasn't a prank. This wasn't some disturbed youth with a printing machine. This was a confession. A manifesto. A promise. He looked from the hateful screed to the silver chalice on his desk, its surface reflecting his own grim face. One represented a covenant of love and redemption. The other, a covenant of hate and annihilation. The Sergeant, the man he tried to keep buried under layers of scripture and pastoral duty, stirred. He folded the pamphlet carefully, tucked it inside his well-worn Bible, and knew, with a certainty that felt like a curse, that this was only the beginning. Frank Miller hadn't started a police investigation. But Rex had. And so, it seemed, had Arthur Hamerton.

His first port of call was not the police station. That would come, but Frank Miller was a man who dealt in facts, not feelings, and Arthur knew the pamphlet, on its own, would be dismissed as the work of a crank. He needed more. The Sergeant knew that you didn't go to your commanding officer with a problem; you went with a problem and a potential solution. Or, at the very least, a direction of attack. The pamphlet was a clue, and the first rule of any investigation was to understand your evidence.

He walked not to the station, but to the Huddersfield Library, a grand Victorian edifice of sandstone and civic pride. Inside, the hushed atmosphere was a comfort, a different kind of sanctuary to St. Jude’s. He found a quiet table in the local history section, the scent of old paper and bookbinder's glue replacing the damp of the vestry. He laid the pamphlet on the polished oak. ‘A SHORT SERMON FOR THE SLOW.’ He examined the paper stock. It was cheap, fibrous, the kind of recycled stuff used in schools or community centres. The printing was the key. It was smudged, the letters slightly bloated. It wasn't a modern laser print or a crisp inkjet job. It was toner-based. A photocopier, and an old one at that, with a dirty drum or a failing fuser unit. The sort of machine a church, a community hall, or a small, cash-strapped business might run until it finally died.

The first was the weapon: not the instrument of death, which was a chilling mystery, but the instrument of communication. The photocopier. Libraries, council-run community centres, struggling small businesses, and, most disquietingly, churches. He turned to the section listing his parishioners, his finger tracing the names. In a small, dusty office behind the vestry, St. Jude’s had its own relic, a hulking Minolta that whirred and groaned like a man on his deathbed. Arthur fed it a sheet of paper and printed a blank page. He held the copy next to Rex’s pamphlet, comparing them under the light of his angle-poise lamp. The toner smudge on his own machine was a consistent vertical line down the right-hand side. The pamphlet’s smudge was a blotchy cloud in the upper-left quadrant. It wasn’t a match. He felt a sliver of relief, quickly extinguished by the scale of the task ahead.

The minister, barely out of theological college, was full of bright-eyed despair about the state of his inherited office equipment. "We've got this absolute beast, Arthur," he lamented. "An old Canon NP-6030. Pre-ark, I think. It works, mostly, but it leaves these awful grey smudges on everything, like a dirty thumbprint in the top corner. The description was so precise, so evocative of the smear on the pamphlet, that the Sergeant in Arthur’s head sat bolt upright. He kept his voice even. "An old Canon, you say? A retired Classics professor from the university, an atheist who only came to church for the Christmas carols and the architecture. Arthur grabbed his jacket. The rain had momentarily eased, leaving the air thick and damp.
